learning_outcomes.description: Apply game theoretic concepts and solution methods to analyse strategic interactions in economic contexts, demonstrating mathematical rigour and logical reasoning.
Determine and justify appropriate theoretical frameworks and equilibrium concepts to model economic scenarios involving strategic interactions.
Critically evaluate the assumptions, predictions, and limitations of game theoretic models when applied to real-world problems involving information asymmetries and strategic behaviour.
Analyse and critique research applications of game theory, assessing how theoretical models contribute to understanding strategic behaviour in economic contexts.
Effectively communicate economic research through oral presentations and written analysis, translating complex theoretical concepts into clear insights for diverse stakeholders.

assessments.task_description:
An open book assignment involving problem solving and/or short answer questions. Questions can be given on any topic covered prior to the midsemester assignment.

Academic Integrity & AI

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: To be submitted via the course blackboard website.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Overview

Students will select and present a research article from a list that will be posted on Blackboard. This INDIVIDUAL presentation assignment requires students to critically analyse the chosen article and communicate the analysis effectively to the class during a tutorial session.

Article Selection & Time Slot Reservation

  • Students must reserve both their chosen article AND presentation time slot on Blackboard on a first-come, first-served basis
  • Presentations will take place during scheduled tutorial sessions

Presentation Requirements

Your presentation must include the following three components:

  • Context & Related Literature
  • Identify and explain the research question addressed in the article
  • Discuss how this research fits within the literature
  • Explain the gap or need this research addresses
  • Analysis
  • Clearly highlight the article's main contribution(s)
  • Explain the significance of the findings or methodological / theoretical insights
  • Discuss the methodology or approach used
  • Future Research
  • Identify limitations and/or unanswered questions from the article
  • Suggest how future research could build upon or extend this work

Assessment Criteria

Students will be evaluated on:

  • Content Quality (75% weight) Accuracy and scope of analysis, critical evaluation, coverage of all three required components, demonstration of knowledge synthesis and evaluation through responses during the Q&A session related to all three components
  • Presentation Style (25% weight): clarity of communication, organisation, time management, effective use of visual aids, and ability to respond thoughtfully and confidently to audience questions

Presentation Format

  • Presentation duration: ca. 10 minutes
  • Slides are recommended but optional (ca. 3-5 content slides)
  • Q&A session to follow each presentation (ca. 5 minutes)
  • Presentations take place during the chosen tutorial session

Important Notes

  • Reserve both your article and time slot well in advance
  • Technical issues (computer problems, internet connectivity) will not be accepted as valid excuses
  • Attendance at your assigned tutorial session is mandatory

Academic Integrity & AI

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: You will receive a mark of 0 if this assessment is submitted late.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date:
13/10/2025

The presentation event will be held in Week 11, with the exact date determined based on the availability of guests, students, and location. This will be communicated well in advance on blackboard. The presentation must be ready by Monday, Week 11.
assessments.task_description:
Overview

Students present their thesis research in front of an audience including invited guests from industry, academia, and/or the public sector at the city campus. Each presentation should be approximately 10 minutes in duration and demonstrate both comprehensive understanding of the student's research and effective application of presentation techniques covered in the presentation skills workshop. Presentations should be accessible to a general academic audience without specialist knowledge of the topic.

The presentation should include and demonstrate:

  • Clear articulation of the research question, methodology, and key findings using language accessible to non-specialists
  • Demonstration of critical understanding of the research context and significance
  • Application of presentation techniques taught in the workshop sessions


Evaluation

Students will be evaluated on factual accuracy, clarity of communication, organisation and structure, time management, effective use of visual aids, ability to effectively communicate their research to the audience, and more generally the demonstration of presentation skills learned throughout the semester.

Academic Integrity & AI

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension independent of AI and MT tools.
